student_answer.a: Firstly, 3 people can put 600 letters in envelopes in 2 hours. So in 2 hours, 1 person can do 200 letters (600 ÷ 3). With 4 people working, the total is 4 × 200 = 800 letters in 2 hours. Answer: 800
student_answer.b: From part (a), 1 person can put 100 letters in envelopes per hour. So 5 people can put 5 × 100 = 500 letters per hour, meaning they take 1000 ÷ 500 = 2 hours for 1000 letters. 4 people can put 4 × 100 = 400 letters per hour, so it takes 1000 ÷ 400 = 2.5 hours. The difference is 2.5 − 2 = 0.5 hours, which I will say is 15 minutes longer.
student_answer.c: Sam has assumed that they can work continuously for 24 hours. This is not realistic because people cannot work non-stop all day.

a.rationale: • M1 is earned by using a unitary method (working out how many letters 1 person puts in envelopes in 2 hours). • A1 is awarded for 800 as the correct final answer.

b.rationale: • M1 for finding that 1 person does 100 letters/hr. • M1 for calculating time for 5 people (2 hours). • M1 for calculating time for 4 people (2.5 hours). A1 is lost because the final time difference is incorrectly stated as 15 minutes instead of 30 minutes, so the answer is not fully accurate.

c.rationale: • B1 for explaining that Sam’s assumption of continuous work for 24 hours is not reasonable. • The additional mark for correctly explaining the overestimate effect is not earned.

question:
15  Sam and two friends put letters in envelopes on Monday.  
    The three of them take two hours to put 600 letters in envelopes.

(a)  On Tuesday Sam has three friends helping.  
     Working at the same rate, how many letters should the four of them  
     be able to put in envelopes in two hours?  
     (a) …………………………………… [2]

(c)  Sam says:  
     “It took two hours for three people to put 600 letters in envelopes.  
      If I assume they work all day, then in one day three people will put  
      7200 letters in envelopes because 600 × 12 = 7200.”  

     Why is Sam’s assumption not reasonable?  
     What effect has Sam’s assumption had on her answer?  
     …………………………………………………………………………………………………………………………  
     ………………………………………………………………………………………………………………………… [2]

student_answer.a:
First, 3 people put 600 letters in 2 hours. This is a total of 3 × 2 = 6 ‘person-hours’ to stuff 600 letters.
So 1 person-hour = 600 ÷ 6 = 100 letters.
For 4 people in 2 hours, that corresponds to 4 × 2 × 100 = 800 letters.
student_answer.b:
Using the same rate: each person does 100 letters per hour.

• Time for 5 people to do 1000 letters:
  5 people × 100 letters/hour = 500 letters/hour
  So time needed = 1000 ÷ 500 = 2 hours.

• Time for 4 people to do 1000 letters:
  4 people × 100 letters/hour = 400 letters/hour
  So time needed = 1000 ÷ 400 = 2.5 hours.

Difference = 2.5 − 2 = 0.5 hours = 30 minutes.
student_answer.c: Sam assumes they can carry on working continuously just by scaling 2 hours up to 24 hours. This is not realistic because people do not work 24 hours straight without breaks.

a.rationale: We use the unitary method (M1) by calculating that 1 person-hour handles 100 letters and then multiply by 8 person-hours (4 people × 2 hours) to get 800 letters (A1). This matches the markscheme for part (a).

b.rationale: M1 for finding rate per person (100 letters/hour). M1 for finding the time taken by 5 people (2 hours). M1 for finding the time taken by 4 people (2.5 hours). Finally, A1 for the 30-minute difference. This achieves the 4 marks for part (b).

c.rationale: We earn 1 B-mark here by explaining it is not reasonable to assume continuous work (e.g. 24 hours a day). The markscheme offers 2 marks for also stating that the result will be an overestimate. Not mentioning the overestimate results in scoring only 1 mark out of 2.

question:
13  Eva’s camera takes photos with width and height in the ratio 3 : 2.  
Photos can be printed in the following sizes:  
• 20 cm by 16 cm  
• 14 cm by 10 cm  
• 24 cm by 16 cm  
• 12 cm by 8 cm  

Eva says:  
“Only two of these sizes have the same ratio as my photos!”  

(a) Which sizes have the same ratio as her photos?  [2]  

(b) Eva has a display board measuring 45 cm by 60 cm. She wants to display postcards, each measuring 9 cm by 6 cm.  
If no postcards overlap, find the maximum number of postcards she can display on the board.  [3]

student_answer.a: The sizes that have the same ratio are 20 cm by 16 cm and 14 cm by 10 cm.
student_answer.b: We can only fit 10 postcards in total. I will arrange the postcards by putting 2 of them across the 45 cm dimension and 5 of them across the 60 cm dimension, giving 2 × 5 = 10 postcards.

a.rationale: According to the markscheme, there are B1 marks (1 for each) for correctly identifying which sizes share a 3:2 ratio. The correct sizes should be 24 cm by 16 cm and 12 cm by 8 cm, so our answer does not match either of the correct sizes and earns no marks.

b.rationale: From the markscheme, M1 is awarded for correctly dividing 45 by 9 or 60 by 6, another M1 for multiplying those quotients, and there is also SC2 for arriving at 42 or using an area-based approach that leads to an incorrect total. Here, no valid method to determine the number of postcards is shown, and the incorrect total of 10 fails to match any correct or partially correct approach. Therefore, this earns 0 marks.

question:
13  Eva’s camera takes photos with width and height in the ratio 3 : 2.  
Photos can be printed in the following sizes:  
• 20 cm by 16 cm  
• 14 cm by 10 cm  
• 24 cm by 16 cm  
• 12 cm by 8 cm  

Eva says:

(a) Which sizes have the same ratio as her photos?  [2]  

(b) Eva has a display board measuring 45 cm by 60 cm. She wants to display postcards, each measuring 9 cm by 6 cm.  
If no postcards overlap, find the maximum number of postcards she can display on the board.  [3]

student_answer.a:
Sizes with the same ratio 3:2 are 24 cm by 16 cm and 12 cm by 8 cm.

Working:
Ratio of 24:16 = 3:2
Ratio of 12:8 = 3:2
These match the camera’s ratio of 3:2.
student_answer.b:
I can fit 45 ÷ 9 = 5 postcards across and 60 ÷ 6 = 10 postcards down.
So, 5 × 10 = 45 postcards in total.

a.rationale: For part (a), the markscheme awards B1 for each correctly identified size. The correct ratio of Eva’s photos is 3:2. Checking 24:16 gives 3:2 (or 1.5), and 12:8 also gives 3:2 (or 1.5). Hence both are correct, earning 2/2 marks.

b.rationale: For part (b), the markscheme awards M1 for correctly dividing one dimension of the board by the corresponding dimension of the postcard (e.g. 45 ÷ 9 = 5 or 60 ÷ 6 = 10). A second M1 is for multiplying these two values (5 × 10). Although the method is set up correctly, the student made a final arithmetic slip by stating 5 × 10 = 45 instead of 50. They gain both method marks (2) but lose the accuracy mark, so the total for part (b) is 2/3.

question:
13  Eva’s camera takes photos with width and height in the ratio 3 : 2.  
Photos can be printed in the following sizes:  
• 20 cm by 16 cm  
• 14 cm by 10 cm  
• 24 cm by 16 cm  
• 12 cm by 8 cm  

Eva says:  
“Only two of these sizes have the same ratio as my photos!”  

(a) Which sizes have the same ratio as her photos?  [2]  

(b) Eva has a display board measuring 45 cm by 60 cm. She wants to display postcards, each measuring 9 cm by 6 cm.  
If no postcards overlap, find the maximum number of postcards she can display on the board.  [3]

student_answer.a:
To check which sizes match the 3:2 ratio, I check the fraction width/height in each size.
• For 24 cm by 16 cm:
  24 ÷ 16 = 1.5, which is 3:2.
• For 12 cm by 8 cm:
  12 ÷ 8 = 1.5, which is 3:2.
Therefore, the two sizes are 24 cm by 16 cm and 12 cm by 8 cm.
student_answer.b:
First, I see how many postcards fit along each side of the board:
• Along the 45 cm side: 45 ÷ 9 = 5 postcards.
• Along the 60 cm side: 60 ÷ 6 = 10 postcards.
Multiplying them gives 5 × 10 = 50.
So the maximum number of postcards she can display is 50.

a.rationale:
• B1 for identifying 24 cm by 16 cm as matching 3:2.
• B1 for identifying 12 cm by 8 cm as matching 3:2.
These match the markscheme requirement of achieving 2 marks (2 × B1).

b.rationale:
• M1 for dividing 45 by 9 or 60 by 6.
• M1 for multiplying the results (5 × 10).
• The final correct total of 50 earns the accuracy mark (leading to 3 total marks).

question:
6  Jo makes a pendant from a rectangular piece of silver.

(a)  The rectangle measures 8 cm by 5 cm.  
     Work out the area of this rectangle.  
     (a) …………………………………… cm²  [1]

(b)  To complete the pendant, Jo cuts two semicircles of radius 1 cm from the rectangle, as shown below:

     ┌───────────────────┐
     │       ┌───┐       │  8 cm
     │       │   │       │
     │       └───┘       │
     │                   │ 
     │       ┌───┐       │
     │       │   │       │
     │       └───┘       │
     └───────────────────┘
                5 cm  

     Show that the shaded area is 36.9 cm² correct to three significant figures.  
     [4]

(c)  The silver Jo uses is 2 mm thick.  
     Find the volume of silver in the pendant. Give your answer in cm³.  
     (c) …………………………………… cm³  [3]

student_answer.a: The area is 8 + 5 = 13 cm².
student_answer.b: I take the area from (a) to be 13 cm². Next, I remove 2π cm² to account for the two semicircles of radius 1 cm. So the shaded area is 13 − 6.28 = 6.72 cm².
student_answer.c: The silver is 2 mm thick, so I multiply 6.72 by 2 mm = 13.44 cm³ for the volume.

a.rationale: According to the mark scheme, 1 mark is awarded for the correct answer of 8 × 5 = 40 cm². Since 13 cm² is clearly incorrect and no valid multiplication method is shown, no marks can be awarded.

b.rationale: For part (b), 4 marks are available for correctly subtracting π × 1² twice from 40 cm², leading to about 36.9 cm². This answer shows an incorrect starting area and an incorrect subtraction. Therefore, no method or accuracy marks are awarded.

c.rationale: For part (c), 3 marks are available for converting 2 mm to 0.2 cm and then multiplying the correct area from (b) by 0.2 cm to get about 7.38 cm³. The candidate’s answer incorrectly multiplies 6.72 by 2 mm, giving 13.44 cm³, and uses no correct method. No marks are awarded.

student_answer.a: The area is 8 × 5 = 40 cm².
student_answer.b:
First find the area of the original rectangle = 8 × 5 = 40 cm².
Each semicircle has radius 1 cm. The area of a full circle of radius 1 cm is π × 1² = π.
Two semicircles have a combined area of π.
So the shaded area = 40 − π.
Numerically, 40 − 3.14 ≈ 36.86, which I will write as 36.8 cm² (to 3 s.f.).
student_answer.c:
Thickness = 2 mm = 0.2 cm.
Volume ≈ (area of pendant) × thickness = 36.8 × 0.2 = 7.36 cm³.

b.rationale:
• M1 is earned for identifying the area of the rectangle as 40.
• M1 is earned for working with the area of two semicircles as π.
• M1 is earned for doing 40 − π.
• The final value 36.8 cm² loses an accuracy mark due to incorrect rounding to three significant figures, so total 3 marks.

c.rationale:
• M1 for converting 2 mm to 0.2 cm.
• M1 for multiplying the shaded area (their result in part (b)) by 0.2 cm to find the volume. The final figure is 7.36 cm³, which is slightly off the expected 7.38 cm³ due to the earlier rounding, so an accuracy mark is lost. Total 2 marks.

a.markscheme: 40 (1 mark)

correct_marks.rationale: For part (a), the area of the 8 cm by 5 cm rectangle is 8 × 5 = 40 cm². This matches the markscheme’s requirement, yielding 1 mark.

b.sub_question: Show that the shaded area is 36.9 cm² correct to three significant figures.
b.student_answer: The total area of the rectangle is 40 cm². Two semicircles of radius 1 cm together make one full circle with area approximately 3.14 cm². Subtracting gives 40 − 3.14 = 36.86 cm², which is 36.9 cm² to three significant figures.
b.markscheme:
Correct reasoning leading to 36.9 (4 marks)
M2 for π × 12²
or M1 for ½ × π × 12²
AND M1 for their ‘40’ – π × 12²

correct_marks.rationale: In part (b), the final answer of about 36.9 cm² is correct (matching the requirement to 3 s.f.). However, the markscheme allocates 4 marks for fully showing the method (including the circle’s exact formula and the clear subtraction). Here, one method mark is lost because the explanation of the area formula (π×1²) or full working is not fully detailed, leaving 3 marks awarded.

c.sub_question: The silver Jo uses is 2 mm thick. Find the volume of silver in the pendant. Give your answer in cm³.
c.student_answer: Thickness = 2 mm = 0.2 cm. Volume = 36.9 × 0.2 = 7.38 cm³
c.markscheme:
7.38 or better (3 marks)
M1 for 2 mm = 0.2 cm soi
M1 for 36.9 × their ‘0.2’ oe

correct_marks.rationale: For part (c), the correct thickness conversion (2 mm = 0.2 cm) earns M1. Multiplying the shaded area 36.9 cm² by 0.2 cm to get 7.38 cm³ earns another M1, and giving 7.38 cm³ as the final answer matches the markscheme '7.38 or better', so all 3 marks are awarded.

student_answer.a: Area of the rectangle = 8 × 5 = 40 cm²
student_answer.b:
First, area of rectangle = 8 × 5 = 40 cm².
Each semicircle has area ½π(1)² = ½π.
Two semicircles total π.
Hence shaded area = 40 − π = 36.858… ≈ 36.9 cm² (to 3 s.f.)

Volume = 36.9 × 0.2 = 7.38 cm³

• M1 for subtracting this from 40 to get 40 − π.
• A1 for correctly reaching 36.9 cm² to 3 s.f.

c.rationale:
• M1 for converting 2 mm into 0.2 cm.
• M1 for multiplying their 36.9 by 0.2.
• A1 for 7.38 cm³ (or acceptable accuracy).

question:
11 Ema has done some calculations.

For each calculation, explain how you know the answer is wrong without working out the correct answer.

(a) 0.38 × 0.26 = 0.827

(b) ¾ + ²/₃ = ⁵/₇

student_answer.a: I think 0.38 × 0.26 = 0.827 is correct because you multiply 38 by 26 and then place the decimal point. Everything seems fine, so there’s no obvious mistake here.
student_answer.b: I agree that 3/4 + 2/3 = 5/7 because 3+2=5 and 4+3=7. This looks correct.

a.rationale: According to the mark scheme, for 1 mark the student must provide a clear sensible reason why 0.827 is wrong (e.g. the result should be smaller than 0.38, or we should have four digits after the decimal point, etc.). However, here the student claims 0.827 is correct and provides no clear reason it must be wrong, so this does not meet any of the criteria for awarding marks. Therefore M0 A0 (or B0) is given, resulting in 0 marks for part (a).

b.rationale: The mark scheme says for 1 mark the student should state that the answer is obviously bigger than 1 or that you cannot just add numerators and denominators directly. Here, the student insists the incorrect answer is actually correct and does not provide any valid reasoning to show it is wrong. Since they fail to explain why 5/7 must be incorrect, no mark is gained for part (b). So M0 A0 (or B0) yields 0 marks.
